results.title: European hand-painted panoramic magic lantern slides
results.brief_description: Magic lantern slides are as varied as they are enchanting. While early slides featured line etchings on glass plates, lanternists were soon hand-painting them to give projections vibrancy and depth.

constellations_primary.name: Directions of storytelling
constellations_primary.description: Panoramic slides gave magic lanternists the ability to progress narratives by adjusting slides left or right. This movement is emblematic of a panning shot where the camera follows the action the natural way your head moves.

results.description: The earliest magic lantern slides were drawn and coloured by hand, using transparent pigments that were most often oil-based. Drawing and colouring wasn’t easy because the slippery glass surface meant the pigment could run, blurring the intended detail. Even worse, the smallest aberrations or errors would be magnified by the projection, so artists needed to be highly skilled and develop specialist tools for these minute details. The changing technology of the magic lantern influenced the way the images were painted and manufactured, with the invention of better illuminates and optical systems demanding even more detailed transparent paintings. Panoramic lantern slides allowed lanternists to progress the narrative without changing over the lantern slides, making for smoother presentations and increased drama and delight from audiences.
description_for_label: The earliest magic lantern slides were drawn and coloured by hand, using transparent pigments that were most often oil-based. Drawing and colouring wasn’t easy because the slippery glass surface meant the pigment could run, blurring the intended detail. Even worse, the smallest aberrations or errors would be magnified by the projection, so artists needed to be highly skilled and develop specialist tools for these minute details. The changing technology of the magic lantern influenced the way the images were painted and manufactured, with the invention of better illuminates and optical systems demanding even more detailed transparent paintings. Panoramic lantern slides allowed lanternists to progress the narrative without changing over the lantern slides, making for smoother presentations and increased drama and delight from audiences.

group_works.title: Equal chances: equal opportunities
group_works.creator_credit: Jean Leduc and Les Films d'Olivier

results.title: European Art School: 4
results.creator_credit: Anders Holmertz and European Art School
results.brief_description: The final of the ‘European Art School’ series, this program discusses guidelines for composition in a range of artistic work including painting and drawing. It outlines how shapes can be geometrical, natural or abstract and the varying effects, some positive, others negative, that this can have on composition. The program also covers how other elements in art, such as balance, colour and movement, can be used to create contrasting or unifying values in the composition of an art work.

results.title: European Art School: 3
results.creator_credit: Anders Holmertz and European Art School
results.brief_description: In this third program, Mario Massanyi and his colleagues explain and explore the principles involved in the use of colour in drawing and painting. They discuss methods of creating your own colour combinations to create varying tints and shades and the evocative qualities of colour to create mood and texture. In painting particularly, they demonstrate the effective methods of creating such mood and texture through the application of paint in a variety of different ways.

results.title: European Art School: 2
results.creator_credit: Anders Holmertz and European Art School
results.brief_description: This program introduces more advanced drawing techniques moving to instruction in the representation of images in three dimensions. Simple shapes like the sphere, cone, cube and cylinder are used as practical examples for drawing and then methods of creating a mood and weathertype or a sense of perspective are explored through the use of particular patterns. The use of different art materials such as charcoal and ink and differing types of paintbrushes are also discussed with attention to their popularity and the quality of those available.

results.title: European Art School: 1
results.creator_credit: Anders Holmertz and European Art School
results.brief_description: Presented by Mario Massanyi and his colleagues this program presents an easy to follow guide to basic drawing and the range of preferred tools that can be used in the process. It covers techniques such as contour drawing, gesture drawing and modelling and highlights practical examples for practicing drawing skills. The episode ends with a tour of a pencil factory where some of the materials discussed earlier in the program are looked at in detail.

results.title: Europe: physical geography
results.brief_description: This film examines the variety and complexity of the natural landscapes of the European continent. Europe displays a surprising wealth of wildlife and natural beauty despite its small size, high population density, and intense industrialization. Students will observe Europe’s long, irregular coastline, from Norway’s fjords to the Black Sea. They will travel to some to some of Europe’s many peninsulas and islands and appreciate the continent’s close links with the sea. They will learn about the effects of the sea on climate and natural vegetation. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s Guide included.

results.title: Europe by train
results.creator_credit: James Ritchie, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: Douglas Brown, journalist and traveller, takes us about Europe telling of his experiences of many different countries: Italy, Switzerland, Germany and Spain. Lingering in stations, or riding on some crack continental expresses, he conveys the excitment of travelling abroad and shows how he makes the journey an interesting part of a holiday or a business trip.
results.creator_credit_for_label: James Ritchie, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films

results.title: Europe after the rain: Dada and Surrealism
results.creator_credit: Mick Gold and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Examines Dada and Surrealism not simply as modern movements in the arts, but also as a history of ideas - emphasising the desire to unify political and psychological values with artistic creativity. Begins with the birth of Dada in Zurich, against the background of the first World War then continues to the Surrealist movement. Describes how Dada and Surrealism attempted to transform the world and how they were transformed by it. Credits: Scriptwriter, Mick Gold.

results.title: Europa nostra
results.creator_credit: Charles Mapleston, Peter Bradford and World Wide Pictures
results.brief_description: Shot in fifteen countries in Western and Eastern Europe, this film touches upon all aspects of conservation, including: treasures lost, restoration, new uses for old buildings, traffic, pressures of tourism, unsightly advertising, and the activities of local authorities and conservation authorities.
